title: Understanding Pelvic Pain
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: Pelvic pain is pain felt in the lower abdomen, between the belly button and the groin. It can come from the reproductive organs, bladder, bowel, muscles, or connective tissues.
Pelvic pain is different from vaginal or vulval pain, which affects the external genital area.

content.title: Key Facts
content.description: Pelvic pain is a very common condition. Most causes are treatable. It can be acute (sudden and short-term) or chronic (lasting several months or more)

items.title: Cyclic Pain
items.description: Related to the menstrual cycle and often occurs before or during periods.

items.title: Non-cyclic Pain
items.description: Not linked to the menstrual cycle.

items.title: Sudden Pain
items.description: Appears suddenly and may be severe.

items.title: Chronic pelvic pain
items.description: Pain that lasts 3 months or longer.

items.title: Gynaecological Causes
items.content:
**Menstrual cramps (dysmenorrhoea)** - Common before or during periods.

**Ovulation pain (mittelschmerz)** - Short-lasting pain mid-cycle, often on one side.

**Endometriosis** - Tissue similar to the womb lining grows outside the uterus.

**Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)** - Infection of the reproductive organs.

**Ectopic pregnancy** - A pregnancy developing outside the womb — a medical emergency.

items.title: Urinary Causes
items.content:
**Cystitis / UTI** - Bladder or urinary tract infection.

**Interstitial cystitis (painful bladder syndrome)** - Long-term bladder pain and urinary symptoms without infection.

**Urinary stones** - Stones in the kidney or urinary tract that can cause severe pain.

items.title: Digestive Causes
items.content:
Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) - Abdominal pain with bloating, constipation, or diarrhoea.

Appendicitis - Sudden pain (often starting centrally then moving to the lower right abdomen) — urgent assessment needed.

content.value: Seek urgent medical help immediately if you have:

items: Sudden, severe pelvic or abdominal pain
Pain with fever, vomiting, or feeling very unwell
Fainting, dizziness, or signs of shock
Severe pain during pregnancy or if pregnancy is possible

content.title: Arrange medical advice promptly if you:
content.description: Notice unexpected vaginal bleeding or unusual discharge, Suspect an infection or STI, Have ongoing pelvic pain that does not improve, Have a known condition (e.g., endometriosis, fibroids) and pain suddenly worsens

content.value: Your doctor will assess your symptoms using a combination of history-taking, examination, and tests.

items.text: Take a detailed medical and menstrual history
Ask about bowel, bladder, and sexual health symptoms
Perform a pelvic examination (if appropriate and with your consent)

items: Swabs to check for infections, including STIs
Laparoscopy (keyhole surgery) if other tests do not explain symptoms or endometriosis is suspected

content.title: Important Note
content.description: Not everyone needs all these tests. The type of investigations depends on your symptoms, age, and medical history.

content.value: Chronic pelvic pain can affect mood, energy levels, sleep, and relationships. It’s common to feel frustrated, anxious, or low when living with ongoing pain.

content.title: Support Available
content.description: Talking to your doctor and asking about emotional support, counselling, or pain management services can help. You don’t have to manage it alone — support is available.

items.title: Track your pain
items.description: Note timing, triggers, severity, and where the pain is felt.

items.title: Use heat therapy
items.description: Warm baths or a hot water bottle can help ease cramps and muscle tension.

items.title: Gentle exercise
items.description: Light movement, stretching, yoga, or walking may help reduce stiffness and improve mood.

items.title: Relaxation and stress management
items.description: Breathing exercises, mindfulness, or relaxation techniques can help manage pain flare-ups.

items.title: Balanced diet and hydration
items.description: Eating regularly and drinking enough fluids supports overall wellbeing.

items.title: Rest when needed
items.description: Pace activities and take breaks when pain increases.

items: Pelvic pain is common and usually treatable
Many causes are not serious, but some need prompt attention
Early assessment can bring relief and peace of mind
